2266  return std::__detail::__chebyshev_w<__type>(__n, __x).__W_n;
2267  }
2268 
2269  // Jacobi polynomials
2270 
2271  /**
2272  * Return the Jacobi polynomial @f$ P_n^{(\alpha,\beta)}(x) @f$
2273  * of degree @f$ n @f$ and @c float orders @f$ \alpha, \beta > -1 @f$
2274  * and argument @f$ x @f$.
2275  *
2276  * @see jacobi for details.
2277  */
2278  inline float
2279  jacobif(unsigned __n, float __alpha, float __beta, float __x)
2280  {
2281  return std::__detail::__jacobi_recur<float>(__n, __alpha, __beta, __x)
2282  .__P_n;
2283  }
2284 
2285  /**
2286  * Return the Jacobi polynomial @f$ P_n^{(\alpha,\beta)}(x) @f$
2287  * of degree @f$ n @f$ and @c <tt>long double</tt> orders
2288  * @f$ \alpha, \beta > -1 @f$ and argument @f$ x @f$.
2289  *
2290  * @see jacobi for details.
2291  */
2292  inline long double
2293  jacobil(unsigned __n, long double __alpha, long double __beta,
2294  long double __x)
2295  {
2296  return std::__detail::__jacobi_recur<long double>(__n, __alpha, __beta, __x)
2297  .__P_n;
2298  }
2299 
2300  /**
2301  * Return the Jacobi polynomial @f$ P_n^{(\alpha,\beta)}(x) @f$
2302  * of degree @f$ n @f$ and @c float orders @f$ \alpha, \beta > -1 @f$
2303  * and argument @f$ x @f$.
2304  *
2305  * The Jacobi polynomials are generated by a three-term recursion relation:
2306  * @f[
2307  * 2 n(\alpha + \beta + n) (\alpha + \beta + 2n - 2)
2308  * P^{(\alpha, \beta)}_{n}(x)
2309  * = (\alpha + \beta + 2n - 1)
2310  * [(\alpha^2 - \beta^2)
2311  * + x(\alpha + \beta + 2n - 2)(\alpha + \beta + 2n)]
2312  * P^{(\alpha, \beta)}_{n-1}(x)
2313  * - 2 (\alpha + n - 1)(\beta + n - 1)(\alpha + \beta + 2n)
2314  * P^{(\alpha, \beta)}_{n-2}(x)
2315  * @f]
2316  * where @f$ P_0^{(\alpha,\beta)}(x) = 1 @f$ and
2317  * @f$ P_1^{(\alpha,\beta)}(x)
2318  * = [(\alpha - \beta) + (\alpha + \beta + 2) x] / 2 @f$.
2319  *
2320  * @tparam _Talpha The real type of the order @f$ \alpha @f$
2321  * @tparam _Tbeta The real type of the order @f$ \beta @f$
2322  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2323  * @param __n The non-negative integral degree
2324  * @param __alpha The real order
2325  * @param __beta The real order
2326  * @param __x The real argument
2327  */
2328  template<typename _Talpha, typename _Tbeta, typename _Tp>
2329  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Talpha, _Tbeta, _Tp>
2330  jacobi(unsigned __n, _Talpha __alpha, _Tbeta __beta, _Tp __x)
2331  {
2332  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Talpha, _Tbeta, _Tp>;
2333  return std::__detail::__jacobi_recur<__type>(__n, __alpha, __beta,
2334  __x).__P_n;
2335  }
2336 
2337  // Gegenbauer polynomials
2338 
2339  /**
2340  * Return the Gegenbauer polynomial @f$ C_n^{(\lambda)}(x) @f$ of degree @c n
2341  * and @c float order @f$ \lambda > -1/2, \lambda \neq 0 @f$
2342  * and argument @f$ x @f$.
2343  *
2344  * @see gegenbauer for details.
2345  */
2346  inline float
2347  gegenbauerf(unsigned int __n, float __lambda, float __x)
2348  { return std::__detail::__gegenbauer_recur<float>(__n, __lambda, __x).__C_n; }
2349 
2350  /**
2351  * Return the Gegenbauer polynomial @f$ C_n^{\lambda}(x) @f$ of degree @c n
2352  * and <tt>long double</tt> order @f$ \lambda > -1/2, \lambda \neq 0 @f$
2353  * and argument @f$ x @f$.
2354  *
2355  * @see gegenbauer for details.
2356  */
2357  inline long double
2358  gegenbauerl(unsigned int __n, long double __lambda, long double __x)
2359  {
2360  return std::__detail::
2361  __gegenbauer_recur<long double>(__n, __lambda, __x).__C_n;
2362  }
2363 
2364  /**
2365  * Return the Gegenbauer polynomial @f$ C_n^{\lambda}(x) @f$ of degree @c n
2366  * and real order @f$ \lambda > -1/2, \lambda \neq 0 @f$ and argument
2367  * @f$ x @f$.
2368  *
2369  * The Gegenbauer polynomial is generated by a three-term recursion relation:
2370  * @f[
2371  * C_n^{\lambda}(x) = \frac{1}{n}\left[ 2x(n+\lambda-1)C_{n-1}^{\lambda}(x)
2372  * - (n+2\lambda-2)C_{n-2}^{\lambda}(x) \right]
2373  * @f]
2374  * and @f$ C_0^{\lambda}(x) = 1 @f$, @f$ C_1^{\lambda}(x) = 2\lambda x @f$.
2375  *
2376  * @tparam _Tlam The real type of the order
2377  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2378  * @param __n The non-negative integral degree
2379  * @param __lambda The real order
2380  * @param __x The real argument
2381  */
2382  template<typename _Tlam, typename _Tp>
2383  inline typename __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tlam, _Tp>
2384  gegenbauer(unsigned int __n, _Tlam __lambda, _Tp __x)
2385  {
2386  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tlam, _Tp>;
2387  return std::__detail::
2388  __gegenbauer_recur<__type>(__n, __lambda, __x).__C_n;
2389  }
2390 
2391  // Zernike polynomials
2392 
2393  /**
2394  * Return the Zernicke polynomial @f$ Z_n^m(\rho,\phi) @f$
2395  * for non-negative degree @f$ n @f$, signed order @f$ m @f$,
2396  * and real radial argument @f$ \rho @f$ and azimuthal angle @f$ \phi @f$.
2397  *
2398  * @see zernike for details.
2399  */
2400  inline float
2401  zernikef(unsigned int __n, int __m, float __rho, float __phi)
2402  { return std::__detail::__zernike<float>(__n, __m, __rho, __phi); }
2403 
2404  /**
2405  * Return the Zernicke polynomial @f$ Z_n^m(\rho,\phi) @f$
2406  * for non-negative degree @f$ n @f$, signed order @f$ m @f$,
2407  * and real radial argument @f$ \rho @f$ and azimuthal angle @f$ \phi @f$.
2408  *
2409  * @see zernike for details.
2410  */
2411  inline long double
2412  zernikel(unsigned int __n, int __m, long double __rho, long double __phi)
2413  { return std::__detail::__zernike<long double>(__n, __m, __rho, __phi); }
2414 
2415  /**
2416  * Return the Zernicke polynomial @f$ Z_n^m(\rho,\phi) @f$
2417  * for non-negative degree @f$ n @f$, signed order @f$ m @f$,
2418  * and real radial argument @f$ \rho @f$ and azimuthal angle @f$ \phi @f$.
2419  *
2420  * The even Zernicke polynomials are defined by:
2421  * @f[
2422  * Z_n^m(\rho,\phi) = R_n^m(\rho)\cos(m\phi)
2423  * @f]
2424  * and the odd Zernicke polynomials are defined by:
2425  * @f[
2426  * Z_n^{-m}(\rho,\phi) = R_n^m(\rho)\sin(m\phi)
2427  * @f]
2428  * for non-negative degree @f$ m @f$ and @f$ m <= n @f$
2429  * and where @f$ R_n^m(\rho) @f$ is the radial polynomial (see radpoly).
2430  *
2431  * @tparam _Trho The real type of the radial coordinate
2432  * @tparam _Tphi The real type of the azimuthal angle
2433  * @param __n The non-negative degree.
2434  * @param __m The (signed) azimuthal order
2435  * @param __rho The radial coordinate
2436  * @param __phi The azimuthal angle
2437  */
2438  template<typename _Trho, typename _Tphi>
2439  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Trho, _Tphi>
2440  zernike(unsigned int __n, int __m, _Trho __rho, _Tphi __phi)
2441  {
2442  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Trho, _Tphi>;
2443  return std::__detail::__zernike<__type>(__n, __m, __rho, __phi);
2444  }
2445 
2446  // Radial polynomials
2447 
2448  /**
2449  * Return the radial polynomial @f$ R_n^m(\rho) @f$ for non-negative
2450  * degree @f$ n @f$, order @f$ m <= n @f$, and @c float radial
2451  * argument @f$ \rho @f$.
2452  *
2453  * @see radpoly for details.
2454  */
2455  inline float
2456  radpolyf(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __m, float __rho)
2457  { return std::__detail::__radial_jacobi(__n, __m, __rho); }
2458 
2459  /**
2460  * Return the radial polynomial @f$ R_n^m(\rho) @f$ for non-negative
2461  * degree @f$ n @f$, order @f$ m <= n @f$, and <tt>long double</tt> radial
2462  * argument @f$ \rho @f$.
2463  *
2464  * @see radpoly for details.
2465  */
2466  inline long double
2467  radpolyl(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __m, long double __rho)
2468  { return std::__detail::__radial_jacobi(__n, __m, __rho); }
2469 
2470  /**
2471  * Return the radial polynomial @f$ R_n^m(\rho) @f$ for non-negative
2472  * degree @f$ n @f$, order @f$ m <= n @f$, and real radial
2473  * argument @f$ \rho @f$.
2474  *
2475  * The radial polynomials are defined by
2476  * @f[
2477  * R_n^m(\rho) = \sum_{k=0}^{\frac{n-m}{2}}
2478  * \frac{(-1)^k(n-k)!}{k!(\frac{n+m}{2}-k)!(\frac{n-m}{2}-k)!}
2479  * \rho^{n-2k}
2480  * @f]
2481  * for @f$ n - m @f$ even and identically 0 for @f$ n - m @f$ odd.
2482  * The radial polynomials can be related to the Jacobi polynomials:
2483  * @f[
2484  * R_n^m(\rho) = (-1)^{(n-m)/2} \rho^m P_{(n-m)/2}^{(m,0)}
2485  * @f]
2486  * @see jacobi for details on the Jacobi polynomials (see jacobi).
2487  *
2488  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the radial coordinate
2489  * @param __n The non-negative degree.
2490  * @param __m The non-negative azimuthal order
2491  * @param __rho The radial argument
2492  */
2493  template<typename _Tp>
2494  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
2495  radpoly(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __m, _Tp __rho)
2496  {
2497  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2498  return std::__detail::__radial_jacobi<__type>(__n, __m, __rho);
2499  }
2500 
2501  // Unnormalized hyperbolic sinus cardinal functions
2502 
2503  /**
2504  * Return the hyperbolic sinus cardinal function @f$ sinhc_\pi(x) @f$
2505  * for @c float argument @c __x.
2506  *
2507  * @see sinhc_pi for details.
2508  */
2509  inline float
2510  sinhc_pif(float __x)
2511  { return std::__detail::__sinhc_pi<float>(__x); }
2512 
2513  /**
2514  * Return the hyperbolic sinus cardinal function @f$ sinhc_\pi(x) @f$
2515  * for <tt>long double</tt> argument @c __x.
2516  *
2517  * @see sinhc_pi for details.
2518  */
2519  inline long double
2520  sinhc_pil(long double __x)
2521  { return std::__detail::__sinhc_pi<long double>(__x); }
2522 
2523  /**
2524  * Return the hyperbolic sinus cardinal function @f$ sinhc_\pi(x) @f$
2525  * for real argument @c __x.
2526  * The sinus cardinal function is defined by:
2527  * @f[
2528  * sinhc_\pi(x) = \frac{\sinh(x)}{x}
2529  * @f]
2530  *
2531  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2532  * @param __x The argument
2533  */
2534  template<typename _Tp>
2535  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
2536  sinhc_pi(_Tp __x)
2537  {
2538  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2539  return std::__detail::__sinhc_pi<__type>(__x);
2540  }
2541 
2542  // Normalized hyperbolic sinus cardinal functions
2543 
2544  /**
2545  * Return the normalized hyperbolic sinus cardinal function @f$ sinhc(x) @f$
2546  * for @c float argument @c __x.
2547  *
2548  * @see sinhc for details.
2549  */
2550  inline float
2551  sinhcf(float __x)
2552  { return std::__detail::__sinhc<float>(__x); }
2553 
2554  /**
2555  * Return the normalized hyperbolic sinus cardinal function @f$ sinhc(x) @f$
2556  * for <tt>long double</tt> argument @c __x.
2557  *
2558  * @see sinhc for details.
2559  */
2560  inline long double
2561  sinhcl(long double __x)
2562  { return std::__detail::__sinhc<long double>(__x); }
2563 
2564  /**
2565  * Return the normalized hyperbolic sinus cardinal function @f$ sinhc(x) @f$
2566  * for real argument @c __x.
2567  * The normalized hyperbolic sinus cardinal function is defined by:
2568  * @f[
2569  * sinhc(x) = \frac{\sinh(\pi x)}{\pi x}
2570  * @f]
2571  *
2572  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2573  * @param __x The argument
2574  */
2575  template<typename _Tp>
2576  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
2577  sinhc(_Tp __x)
2578  {
2579  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2580  return std::__detail::__sinhc<__type>(__x);
2581  }
2582 
2583  // Cylindrical Hankel functions of the first kind
2584 
2585  /**
2586  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the first kind
2587  * @f$ H^{(1)}_\nu(x) @f$ of @c float order @f$ \nu @f$
2588  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2589  *
2590  * @see cyl_hankel_1 for details.
2591  */
2592  inline std::complex<float>
2593  cyl_hankel_1f(float __nu, float __z)
2594  { return std::__detail::__cyl_hankel_1<float>(__nu, __z); }
2595 
2596  /**
2597  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the first kind
2598  * @f$ H^{(1)}_\nu(x) @f$ of <tt>long double</tt> order @f$ \nu @f$
2599  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2600  *
2601  * @see cyl_hankel_1 for details.
2602  */
2603  inline std::complex<long double>
2604  cyl_hankel_1l(long double __nu, long double __z)
2605  { return std::__detail::__cyl_hankel_1<long double>(__nu, __z); }
2606 
2607  /**
2608  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the first kind
2609  * @f$ H^{(1)}_n(x) @f$ of real order @f$ \nu @f$
2610  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2611  *
2612  * The spherical Hankel function of the first kind is defined by:
2613  * @f[
2614  * H^{(1)}_\nu(x) = J_\nu(x) + iN_\nu(x)
2615  * @f]
2616  * where @f$ J_\nu(x) @f$ and @f$ N_\nu(x) @f$ are the cylindrical Bessel
2617  * and Neumann functions respectively (see cyl_bessel and cyl_neumann).
2618  *
2619  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2620  * @param __nu The real order
2621  * @param __z The real argument
2622  */
2623  template<typename _Tpnu, typename _Tp>
2624  inline std::complex<__gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tpnu, _Tp>>
2625  cyl_hankel_1(_Tpnu __nu, _Tp __z)
2626  {
2627  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tpnu, _Tp>;
2628  return std::__detail::__cyl_hankel_1<__type>(__nu, __z);
2629  }
2630 
2631  // Cylindrical Hankel functions of the second kind
2632 
2633  /**
2634  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the second kind
2635  * @f$ H^{(2)}_\nu(x) @f$ of @c float order @f$ \nu @f$
2636  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2637  *
2638  * @see cyl_hankel_2 for details.
2639  */
2640  inline std::complex<float>
2641  cyl_hankel_2f(float __nu, float __z)
2642  { return std::__detail::__cyl_hankel_2<float>(__nu, __z); }
2643 
2644  /**
2645  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the second kind
2646  * @f$ H^{(2)}_\nu(x) @f$ of <tt>long double</tt> order @f$ \nu @f$
2647  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2648  *
2649  * @see cyl_hankel_2 for details.
2650  */
2651  inline std::complex<long double>
2652  cyl_hankel_2l(long double __nu, long double __z)
2653  { return std::__detail::__cyl_hankel_2<long double>(__nu, __z); }
2654 
2655  /**
2656  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the second kind
2657  * @f$ H^{(2)}_n(x) @f$ of real order @f$ \nu @f$
2658  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2659  *
2660  * The cylindrical Hankel function of the second kind is defined by:
2661  * @f[
2662  * H^{(2)}_\nu(x) = J_\nu(x) - iN_\nu(x)
2663  * @f]
2664  * where @f$ J_\nu(x) @f$ and @f$ N_\nu(x) @f$ are the cylindrical Bessel
2665  * and Neumann functions respectively (see cyl_bessel and cyl_neumann).
2666  *
2667  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2668  * @param __nu The real order
2669  * @param __z The real argument
2670  */
2671  template<typename _Tpnu, typename _Tp>
2672  inline std::complex<__gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tpnu, _Tp>>
2673  cyl_hankel_2(_Tpnu __nu, _Tp __z)
2674  {
2675  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tpnu, _Tp>;
2676  return std::__detail::__cyl_hankel_2<__type>(__nu, __z);
2677  }
2678 
2679  // Spherical Hankel functions of the first kind
2680 
2681  /**
2682  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the first kind @f$ h^{(1)}_n(x) @f$
2683  * of nonnegative order n and @c float argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2684  *
2685  * @see sph_hankel_1 for details.
2686  */
2687  inline std::complex<float>
2688  sph_hankel_1f(unsigned int __n, float __z)
2689  { return std::__detail::__sph_hankel_1<float>(__n, __z); }
2690 
2691  /**
2692  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the first kind @f$ h^{(1)}_n(x) @f$
2693  * of nonnegative order n and @c <tt>long double</tt> argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2694  *
2695  * @see sph_hankel_1 for details.
2696  */
2697  inline std::complex<long double>
2698  sph_hankel_1l(unsigned int __n, long double __z)
2699  { return std::__detail::__sph_hankel_1<long double>(__n, __z); }
2700 
2701  /**
2702  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the first kind @f$ h^{(1)}_n(x) @f$
2703  * of nonnegative order @f$ n @f$ and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2704  *
2705  * The spherical Hankel function of the first kind is defined by:
2706  * @f[
2707  * h^{(1)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} H^{(1)}_{n+1/2}(x)
2708  * @f]
2709  * or in terms of the cylindrical Bessel and Neumann functions by:
2710  * @f[
2711  * h^{(1)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2}
2712  * \left[ J_{n+1/2}(x) + iN_{n+1/2}(x) \right]
2713  * @f]
2714  *
2715  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2716  * @param __n The non-negative order
2717  * @param __z The real argument
2718  */
2719  template<typename _Tp>
2720  inline std::complex<__gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>>
2721  sph_hankel_1(unsigned int __n, _Tp __z)
2722  {
2723  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2724  return std::__detail::__sph_hankel_1<__type>(__n, __z);
2725  }
2726 
2727  // Spherical Hankel functions of the second kind
2728 
2729  /**
2730  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the second kind @f$ h^{(2)}_n(x)@f$
2731  * of nonnegative order n and @c float argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2732  *
2733  * @see sph_hankel_2 for details.
2734  */
2735  inline std::complex<float>
2736  sph_hankel_2f(unsigned int __n, float __z)
2737  { return std::__detail::__sph_hankel_2<float>(__n, __z); }
2738 
2739  /**
2740  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the second kind @f$ h^{(2)}_n(x)@f$
2741  * of nonnegative order n and @c <tt>long double</tt> argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2742  *
2743  * @see sph_hankel_2 for details.
2744  */
2745  inline std::complex<long double>
2746  sph_hankel_2l(unsigned int __n, long double __z)
2747  { return std::__detail::__sph_hankel_2<long double>(__n, __z); }
2748 
2749  /**
2750  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the second kind @f$ h^{(2)}_n(x)@f$
2751  * of nonnegative order @f$ n @f$ and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2752  *
2753  * The spherical Hankel function of the second kind is defined by:
2754  * @f[
2755  * h^{(2)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} H^{(2)}_{n+1/2}(x)
2756  * @f]
2757  * or in terms of the cylindrical Bessel and Neumann functions by:
2758  * @f[
2759  * h^{(2)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2}
2760  * \left[ J_{n+1/2}(x) - iN_{n+1/2}(x) \right]
2761  * @f]
2762  *
2763  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2764  * @param __n The non-negative order
2765  * @param __z The real argument
2766  */
2767  template<typename _Tp>
2768  inline std::complex<__gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>>
2769  sph_hankel_2(unsigned int __n, _Tp __z)
2770  {
2771  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2772  return std::__detail::__sph_hankel_2<__type>(__n, __z);
2773  }
2774 
2775  // Modified spherical Bessel functions of the first kind
2776 
2777  /**
2778  * Return the regular modified spherical Bessel function @f$ i_n(x) @f$
2779  * of nonnegative order n and @c float argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2780  *
2781  * @see sph_bessel_i for details.
2782  */
2783  inline float
2784  sph_bessel_if(unsigned int __n, float __x)
2785  { std::__detail::__sph_bessel_ik<float>(__n, __x).__i_value; }
2786 
2787  /**
2788  * Return the regular modified spherical Bessel function @f$ i_n(x) @f$
2789  * of nonnegative order n and <tt>long double</tt> argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2790  *
2791  * @see sph_bessel_i for details.
2792  */
2793  inline long double
2794  sph_bessel_il(unsigned int __n, long double __x)
2795  { return std::__detail::__sph_bessel_ik<long double>(__n, __x).__i_value; }
2796 
2797  /**
2798  * Return the regular modified spherical Bessel function @f$ i_n(x) @f$
2799  * of nonnegative order n and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2800  *
2801  * The spherical Bessel function is defined by:
2802  * @f[
2803  * i_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} I_{n+1/2}(x)
2804  * @f]
2805  *
2806  * @tparam _Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c __x.
2807  * @param __n The integral order <tt> n >= 0 </tt>
2808  * @param __x The real argument <tt> x >= 0 </tt>
2809  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> __x < 0 </tt>.
2810  */
2811  template<typename _Tp>
2812  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
2813  sph_bessel_i(unsigned int __n, _Tp __x)
2814  {
2815  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2816  return std::__detail::__sph_bessel_ik<__type>(__n, __x).__i_value;
2817  }
2818 
2819  // Modified spherical Bessel functions of the second kind
2820 
2821  /**
2822  * Return the irregular modified spherical Bessel function @f$ k_n(x) @f$
2823  * of nonnegative order n and @c float argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2824  *
2825  * @see sph_bessel_k for more details.
2826  */
2827  inline float
2828  sph_bessel_kf(unsigned int __n, float __x)
2829  { return std::__detail::__sph_bessel_ik<float>(__n, __x).__k_value; }
2830 
2831  /**
2832  * Return the irregular modified spherical Bessel function @f$ k_n(x) @f$
2833  * of nonnegative order n and <tt>long double</tt> argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2834  *
2835  * @see sph_bessel_k for more details.
2836  */
2837  inline long double
2838  sph_bessel_kl(unsigned int __n, long double __x)
2839  { return std::__detail::__sph_bessel_ik<long double>(__n, __x).__k_value; }
2840 
2841  /**
2842  * Return the irregular modified spherical Bessel function @f$ k_n(x) @f$
2843  * of nonnegative order n and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
2844  *
2845  * The spherical Bessel function is defined by:
2846  * @f[
2847  * k_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} K_{n+1/2}(x)
2848  * @f]
2849  *
2850  * @tparam _Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c __x.
2851  * @param __n The integral order <tt> n >= 0 </tt>
2852  * @param __x The real argument <tt> x >= 0 </tt>
2853  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> __x < 0 </tt>.
2854  */
2855  template<typename _Tp>
2856  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
2857  sph_bessel_k(unsigned int __n, _Tp __x)
2858  {
2859  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2860  return std::__detail::__sph_bessel_ik<__type>(__n, __x).__k_value;
2861  }
2862 
2863  // Airy functions of the first kind
2864 
2865  /**
2866  * Return the Airy function @f$ Ai(x) @f$ for @c float argument @f$ x @f$.
2867  *
2868  * @see airy_ai for details.
2869  */
2870  inline float
2871  airy_aif(float __x)
2872  { return std::__detail::__airy<float>(__x).__Ai_value; }
2873 
2874  /**
2875  * Return the Airy function @f$ Ai(x) @f$ for <tt>long double</tt>
2876  * argument @f$ x @f$.
2877  *
2878  * @see airy_ai for details.
2879  */
2880  inline long double
2881  airy_ail(long double __x)
2882  { return std::__detail::__airy<long double>(__x).__Ai_value; }
2883 
2884  /**
2885  * Return the Airy function @f$ Ai(x) @f$ of real argument @f$ x @f$.
2886  *
2887  * The Airy function is defined by:
2888  * @f[
2889  * Ai(x) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^\infty
2890  * \cos \left(\frac{t^3}{3} + xt \right)dt
2891  * @f]
2892  *
2893  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2894  * @param __x The argument
2895  */
2896  template<typename _Tp>
2897  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
2898  airy_ai(_Tp __x)
2899  {
2900  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2901  return std::__detail::__airy<__type>(__x).__Ai_value;
2902  }
2903 
2904  /**
2905  * Return the Airy function @f$ Ai(x) @f$ of complex argument @f$ x @f$.
2906  *
2907  * The Airy function is defined by:
2908  * @f[
2909  * Ai(x) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^\infty
2910  * \cos \left(\frac{t^3}{3} + xt \right)dt
2911  * @f]
2912  *
2913  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2914  * @param __x The complex argument
2915  */
2916  template<typename _Tp>
2917  inline std::complex<__gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>>
2918  airy_ai(std::complex<_Tp> __x)
2919  {
2920  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2921  return std::__detail::__airy_ai<__type>(__x);
2922  }
2923 
2924  // Airy functions of the second kind
2925 
2926  /**
2927  * Return the Airy function @f$ Bi(x) @f$ for @c float argument @f$ x @f$.
2928  *
2929  * @see airy_bi for details.
2930  */
2931  inline float
2932  airy_bif(float __x)
2933  { return std::__detail::__airy<float>(__x).__Bi_value; }
2934 
2935  /**
2936  * Return the Airy function @f$ Bi(x) @f$ for <tt>long double</tt>
2937  * argument @f$ x @f$.
2938  *
2939  * @see airy_bi for details.
2940  */
2941  inline long double
2942  airy_bil(long double __x)
2943  { return std::__detail::__airy<long double>(__x).__Bi_value; }
2944 
2945  /**
2946  * Return the Airy function @f$ Bi(x) @f$ of real argument @f$ x @f$.
2947  *
2948  * The Airy function is defined by:
2949  * @f[
2950  * Bi(x) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^\infty \left[
2951  * \exp \left(-\frac{t^3}{3} + xt \right)
2952  * + \sin \left(\frac{t^3}{3} + xt \right) \right] dt
2953  * @f]
2954  *
2955  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2956  * @param __x The argument
2957  */
2958  template<typename _Tp>
2959  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
2960  airy_bi(_Tp __x)
2961  {
2962  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2963  return std::__detail::__airy<__type>(__x).__Bi_value;
2964  }
2965 
2966  /**
2967  * Return the Airy function @f$ Bi(x) @f$ of complex argument @f$ x @f$.
2968  *
2969  * The Airy function is defined by:
2970  * @f[
2971  * Bi(x) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^\infty \left[
2972  * \exp \left(-\frac{t^3}{3} + xt \right)
2973  * + \sin \left(\frac{t^3}{3} + xt \right) \right] dt
2974  * @f]
2975  *
2976  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
2977  * @param __x The complex argument
2978  */
2979  template<typename _Tp>
2980  inline std::complex<__gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>>
2981  airy_bi(std::complex<_Tp> __x)
2982  {
2983  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
2984  return std::__detail::__airy_bi<__type>(__x);
2985  }
2986 
2987  // Log Gamma function for real argument.
2988 
2989  /**
2990  * Return the logarithm of the gamma function for
2991  * <tt> float </tt> argument.
2992  *
2993  * @see lgamma for details.
2994  */
2995  inline float
2996  lgammaf(float __a)
2997  { return std::__detail::__log_gamma<float>(__a); }
2998 
2999  /**
3000  * Return the logarithm of the gamma function for
3001  * <tt> long double </tt> argument.
3002  *
3003  * @see lgamma for details.
3004  */
3005  inline long double
3006  lgammal(long double __a)
3007  { return std::__detail::__log_gamma<long double>(__a); }
3008

3010  * Return the logarithm of the gamma function for real argument.
3011  */

3013  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta>
3014  lgamma(_Ta __a)
3015  {
3016  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta>;
3017  return std::__detail::__log_gamma<__type>(__a);
3018  }

3026  * @see lgamma for details.

3103  tgammal(std::complex<long double> __a)
3104  { return std::__detail::__gamma<std::complex<long double>>(__a); }

3116 
3117  // Upper incomplete gamma functions
3118 
3119  /**
3120  * Return the upper incomplete gamma function @f$ \Gamma(a,x) @f$
3121  * for @c float argument.
3122  *
3123  * @see tgamma for details.
3124  */
3125  inline float
3126  tgammaf(float __a, float __x)
3127  { return std::__detail::__tgamma<float>(__a, __x); }
3128 
3129  /**
3130  * Return the upper incomplete gamma function @f$ \Gamma(a,x) @f$
3131  * for <tt>long double</tt> argument.
3132  *
3133  * @see tgamma for details.
3134  */
3135  inline long double
3136  tgammal(long double __a, long double __x)
3137  { return std::__detail::__tgamma<long double>(__a, __x); }
3138 
3139  /**
3140  * Return the upper incomplete gamma function @f$ \Gamma(a,x) @f$.
3141  * The (upper) incomplete gamma function is defined by
3142  * @f[
3143  * \Gamma(a,x) = \int_x^\infty t^{a-1}e^{-t}dt
3144  * @f]
3145  */
3146  template<typename _Ta, typename _Tp>
3147  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>
3148  tgamma(_Ta __a, _Tp __x)
3149  {
3150  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>;
3151  return std::__detail::__tgamma<__type>(__a, __x);
3152  }
3153 
3154  // Lower incomplete gamma functions
3155 
3156  /**
3157  * Return the lower incomplete gamma function @f$ \gamma(a,x) @f$
3158  * for @c float argument.
3159  *
3160  * @see tgamma_lower for details.
3161  */
3162  inline float
3163  tgamma_lowerf(float __a, float __x)
3164  { return std::__detail::__tgamma_lower<float>(__a, __x); }
3165 
3166  /**
3167  * Return the lower incomplete gamma function @f$ \gamma(a,x) @f$
3168  * for <tt>long double</tt> argument.
3169  *
3170  * @see tgamma_lower for details.
3171  */
3172  inline long double
3173  tgamma_lowerl(long double __a, long double __x)
3174  { return std::__detail::__tgamma_lower<long double>(__a, __x); }
3175 
3176  /**
3177  * Return the lower incomplete gamma function @f$ \gamma(a,x) @f$.
3178  * The lower incomplete gamma function is defined by
3179  * @f[
3180  * \gamma(a,x) = \int_0^x t^{a-1}e^{-t}dt
3181  * @f]
3182  */
3183  template<typename _Ta, typename _Tp>
3184  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>
3185  tgamma_lower(_Ta __a, _Tp __x)
3186  {
3187  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>;
3188  return std::__detail::__tgamma_lower<__type>(__a, __x);
3189  }
3190 
3191  // Dilogarithm functions
3192 
3193  /**
3194  * Return the dilogarithm function @f$ Li_2(z) @f$
3195  * for @c float argument.
3196  *
3197  * @see dilog for details.
3198  */
3199  inline float
3200  dilogf(float __x)
3201  { return std::__detail::__dilog<float>(__x); }
3202 
3203  /**
3204  * Return the dilogarithm function @f$ Li_2(z) @f$
3205  * for <tt>long double</tt> argument.
3206  *
3207  * @see dilog for details.
3208  */
3209  inline long double
3210  dilogl(long double __x)
3211  { return std::__detail::__dilog<long double>(__x); }
3212 
3213  /**
3214  * Return the dilogarithm function @f$ Li_2(z) @f$
3215  * for real argument.
3216  *
3217  * The dilogarithm is defined by:
3218  * @f[
3219  * Li_2(x) = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{x^k}{k^2}
3220  * @f]
3221  *
3222  * @param __x The argument.
3223  */
3224  template<typename _Tp>
3225  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3226  dilog(_Tp __x)
3227  {
3228  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3229  return std::__detail::__dilog<__type>(__x);
3230  }
3231 
3232  // Complete Carlson elliptic R_F functions
3233 
3234  /**
3235  * Return the complete Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y,z) @f$
3236  * for @c float arguments.
3237  *
3238  * @see comp_ellint_rf for details.
3239  */
3240  inline float
3241  comp_ellint_rf(float __x, float __y)
3242  { return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_rf<float>(__x, __y); }
3243 
3244  /**
3245  * Return the complete Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y) @f$
3246  * for <tt>long double</tt> arguments.
3247  *
3248  * @see comp_ellint_rf for details.
3249  */
3250  inline long double
3251  comp_ellint_rf(long double __x, long double __y)
3252  { return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_rf<long double>(__x, __y); }
3253 
3254  /**
3255  * Return the complete Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y) @f$
3256  * for real arguments.
3257  *
3258  * The complete Carlson elliptic function of the first kind is defined by:
3259  * @f[
3260  * R_F(x,y) = R_F(x,y,y) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty
3261  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)}
3262  * @f]
3263  *
3264  * @param __x The first argument.
3265  * @param __y The second argument.
3266  */
3267  template<typename _Tx, typename _Ty>
3268  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>
3269  comp_ellint_rf(_Tx __x, _Ty __y)
3270  {
3271  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>;
3272  return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_rf<__type>(__x, __y);
3273  }
3274 
3275  // Carlson elliptic R_F functions
3276 
3277  /**
3278  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y,z) @f$
3279  * of the first kind for @c float arguments.
3280  *
3281  * @see ellint_rf for details.
3282  */
3283  inline float
3284  ellint_rff(float __x, float __y, float __z)
3285  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rf<float>(__x, __y, __z); }
3286 
3287  /**
3288  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y,z) @f$
3289  * of the first kind for <tt>long double</tt> arguments.
3290  *
3291  * @see ellint_rf for details.
3292  */
3293  inline long double
3294  ellint_rfl(long double __x, long double __y, long double __z)
3295  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rf<long double>(__x, __y, __z); }
3296 
3297  /**
3298  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_F(x,y,z) @f$
3299  * of the first kind for real arguments.
3300  *
3301  * The Carlson elliptic function of the first kind is defined by:
3302  * @f[
3303  * R_F(x,y,z) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty
3304  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)^{1/2}(t + z)^{1/2}}
3305  * @f]
3306  *
3307  * @param __x The first of three symmetric arguments.
3308  * @param __y The second of three symmetric arguments.
3309  * @param __z The third of three symmetric arguments.
3310  */
3311  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp>
3312  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp>
3313  ellint_rf(_Tp __x, _Up __y, _Vp __z)
3314  {
3315  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp>;
3316  return std::__detail::__ellint_rf<__type>(__x, __y, __z);
3317  }
3318 
3319  // Carlson elliptic R_C functions
3320 
3321  /**
3322  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_C(x,y) @f$.
3323  *
3324  * @see ellint_rc for details.
3325  */
3326  inline float
3327  ellint_rcf(float __x, float __y)
3328  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rc<float>(__x, __y); }
3329 
3330  /**
3331  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_C(x,y) @f$.
3332  *
3333  * @see ellint_rc for details.
3334  */
3335  inline long double
3336  ellint_rcl(long double __x, long double __y)
3337  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rc<long double>(__x, __y); }
3338 
3339  /**
3340  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_C(x,y) = R_F(x,y,y) @f$
3341  * where @f$ R_F(x,y,z) @f$ is the Carlson elliptic function
3342  * of the first kind.
3343  *
3344  * The Carlson elliptic function is defined by:
3345  * @f[
3346  * R_C(x,y) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty
3347  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)}
3348  * @f]
3349  *
3350  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
3351  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
3352  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
3353  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
3354  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
3355  *
3356  * @param __x The first argument.
3357  * @param __y The second argument.
3358  */
3359  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up>
3360  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up>
3361  ellint_rc(_Tp __x, _Up __y)
3362  {
3363  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up>;
3364  return std::__detail::__ellint_rc<__type>(__x, __y);
3365  }
3366 
3367  // Carlson elliptic R_J functions
3368 
3369  /**
3370  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_J(x,y,z,p) @f$.
3371  *
3372  * @see ellint_rj for details.
3373  */
3374  inline float
3375  ellint_rjf(float __x, float __y, float __z, float __p)
3376  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rj<float>(__x, __y, __z, __p); }
3377 
3378  /**
3379  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_J(x,y,z,p) @f$.
3380  *
3381  * @see ellint_rj for details.
3382  */
3383  inline long double
3384  ellint_rjl(long double __x, long double __y, long double __z, long double __p)
3385  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rj<long double>(__x, __y, __z, __p); }
3386 
3387  /**
3388  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_J(x,y,z,p) @f$
3389  * of the third kind.
3390  *
3391  * The Carlson elliptic function of the third kind is defined by:
3392  * @f[
3393  * R_J(x,y,z,p) = \frac{3}{2} \int_0^\infty
3394  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)^{1/2}(t + z)^{1/2}(t + p)}
3395  * @f]
3396  *
3397  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
3398  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
3399  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
3400  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
3401  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
3402  *
3403  * @param __x The first of three symmetric arguments.
3404  * @param __y The second of three symmetric arguments.
3405  * @param __z The third of three symmetric arguments.
3406  * @param __p The fourth argument.
3407  */
3408  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp, typename _Wp>
3409  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp, _Wp>
3410  ellint_rj(_Tp __x, _Up __y, _Vp __z, _Wp __p)
3411  {
3412  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp, _Wp>;
3413  return std::__detail::__ellint_rj<__type>(__x, __y, __z, __p);
3414  }
3415 
3416  // Carlson elliptic R_D functions
3417 
3418  /**
3419  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_D(x,y,z) @f$.
3420  *
3421  * @see ellint_rd for details.
3422  */
3423  inline float
3424  ellint_rdf(float __x, float __y, float __z)
3425  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rd<float>(__x, __y, __z); }
3426 
3427  /**
3428  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_D(x,y,z) @f$.
3429  *
3430  * @see ellint_rd for details.
3431  */
3432  inline long double
3433  ellint_rdl(long double __x, long double __y, long double __z)
3434  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rd<long double>(__x, __y, __z); }
3435 
3436  /**
3437  * Return the Carlson elliptic function of the second kind
3438  * @f$ R_D(x,y,z) = R_J(x,y,z,z) @f$ where
3439  * @f$ R_J(x,y,z,p) @f$ is the Carlson elliptic function
3440  * of the third kind.
3441  *
3442  * The Carlson elliptic function of the second kind is defined by:
3443  * @f[
3444  * R_D(x,y,z) = \frac{3}{2} \int_0^\infty
3445  * \frac{dt}{(t + x)^{1/2}(t + y)^{1/2}(t + z)^{3/2}}
3446  * @f]
3447  *
3448  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
3449  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
3450  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
3451  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
3452  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
3453  *
3454  * @param __x The first of two symmetric arguments.
3455  * @param __y The second of two symmetric arguments.
3456  * @param __z The third argument.
3457  */
3458  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp>
3459  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp>
3460  ellint_rd(_Tp __x, _Up __y, _Vp __z)
3461  {
3462  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp>;
3463  return std::__detail::__ellint_rd<__type>(__x, __y, __z);
3464  }
3465 
3466  // Complete Carlson elliptic R_G functions
3467 
3468  /**
3469  * Return the Carlson complementary elliptic function @f$ R_G(x,y) @f$.
3470  *
3471  * @see comp_ellint_rg for details.
3472  */
3473  inline float
3474  comp_ellint_rg(float __x, float __y)
3475  { return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_rg<float>(__x, __y); }
3476 
3477  /**
3478  * Return the Carlson complementary elliptic function @f$ R_G(x,y) @f$.
3479  *
3480  * @see comp_ellint_rg for details.
3481  */
3482  inline long double
3483  comp_ellint_rg(long double __x, long double __y)
3484  { return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_rg<long double>(__x, __y); }
3485 
3486  /**
3487  * Return the complete Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_G(x,y) @f$
3488  * for real arguments.
3489  *
3490  * The complete Carlson elliptic function is defined by:
3491  * @f[
3492  * R_G(x,y) = R_G(x,y,y) = \frac{1}{4} \int_0^\infty
3493  * dt t (t + x)^{-1/2}(t + y)^{-1}
3494  * \left(\frac{x}{t + x} + \frac{2y}{t + y}\right)
3495  * @f]
3496  *
3497  * @param __x The first argument.
3498  * @param __y The second argument.
3499  */
3500  template<typename _Tx, typename _Ty>
3501  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>
3502  comp_ellint_rg(_Tx __x, _Ty __y)
3503  {
3504  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tx, _Ty>;
3505  return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_rg<__type>(__x, __y);
3506  }
3507 
3508  // Carlson elliptic R_G functions
3509 
3510  /**
3511  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_G(x,y) @f$.
3512  *
3513  * @see ellint_rg for details.
3514  */
3515  inline float
3516  ellint_rgf(float __x, float __y, float __z)
3517  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rg<float>(__x, __y, __z); }
3518 
3519  /**
3520  * Return the Carlson elliptic function @f$ R_G(x,y) @f$.
3521  *
3522  * @see ellint_rg for details.
3523  */
3524  inline long double
3525  ellint_rgl(long double __x, long double __y, long double __z)
3526  { return std::__detail::__ellint_rg<long double>(__x, __y, __z); }
3527 
3528  /**
3529  * Return the symmetric Carlson elliptic function of the second kind
3530  * @f$ R_G(x,y,z) @f$.
3531  *
3532  * The Carlson symmetric elliptic function of the second kind is defined by:
3533  * @f[
3534  * R_G(x,y,z) = \frac{1}{4} \int_0^\infty
3535  * dt t [(t + x)(t + y)(t + z)]^{-1/2}
3536  * (\frac{x}{t + x} + \frac{y}{t + y} + \frac{z}{t + z})
3537  * @f]
3538  *
3539  * Based on Carlson's algorithms:
3540  * - B. C. Carlson Numer. Math. 33, 1 (1979)
3541  * - B. C. Carlson, Special Functions of Applied Mathematics (1977)
3542  * - Numerical Recipes in C, 2nd ed, pp. 261-269,
3543  * by Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery (1992)
3544  *
3545  * @param __x The first of three symmetric arguments.
3546  * @param __y The second of three symmetric arguments.
3547  * @param __z The third of three symmetric arguments.
3548  */
3549  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up, typename _Vp>
3550  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp>
3551  ellint_rg(_Tp __x, _Up __y, _Vp __z)
3552  {
3553  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up, _Vp>;
3554  return std::__detail::__ellint_rg<__type>(__x, __y, __z);
3555  }
3556 
3557  // Hurwitz zeta functions
3558 
3559  /**
3560  * Return the Hurwitz zeta function of @c float argument @f$ s @f$,
3561  * and parameter @f$ a @f$.
3562  *
3563  * @see hurwitz_zeta for details.
3564  */
3565  inline float
3566  hurwitz_zetaf(float __s, float __a)
3567  { return std::__detail::__hurwitz_zeta<float>(__s, __a); }
3568 
3569  /**
3570  * Return the Hurwitz zeta function of <tt>long double</tt>
3571  * argument @f$ s @f$, and parameter @f$ a @f$.
3572  *
3573  * @see hurwitz_zeta for details.
3574  */
3575  inline long double
3576  hurwitz_zetal(long double __s, long double __a)
3577  { return std::__detail::__hurwitz_zeta<long double>(__s, __a); }
3578 
3579  /**
3580  * Return the Hurwitz zeta function of real argument @f$ s @f$,
3581  * and parameter @f$ a @f$.
3582  *
3583  * The the Hurwitz zeta function is defined by
3584  * @f[
3585  * \zeta(s, a) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(a + n)^s}
3586  * @f]
3587  *
3588  * @param __s The order.
3589  * @param __a The parameter.
3590  */
3591  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up>
3592  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up>
3593  hurwitz_zeta(_Tp __s, _Up __a)
3594  {
3595  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up>;
3596  return std::__detail::__hurwitz_zeta<__type>(__s, __a);
3597  }
3598 
3599  /**
3600  * Return the Hurwitz zeta function of real order @f$ s @f$,
3601  * and complex parameter @f$ a @f$.
3602  *
3603  * @see hurwitz_zeta for details.
3604  */
3605  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up>
3606  std::complex<_Tp>
3607  hurwitz_zeta(_Tp __s, std::complex<_Up> __a)
3608  {
3609  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up>;
3610  return std::__detail::__hurwitz_zeta_polylog<__type>(__s, __a);
3611  }
3612 
3613  // Periodic zeta functions
3614 
3615  /**
3616  * Return the periodic zeta function of @c float argument @f$ x @f$,
3617  * and parameter @f$ s @f$.
3618  *
3619  * @see periodic_zeta for details.
3620  */
3621  inline std::complex<float>
3622  periodic_zetaf(float __x, float __s)
3623  { return std::__detail::__periodic_zeta<float>(__x, __s); }
3624 
3625  /**
3626  * Return the periodic zeta function of <tt>long double</tt>
3627  * argument @f$ x @f$, and parameter @f$ s @f$.
3628  *
3629  * @see periodic_zeta for details.
3630  */
3631  inline std::complex<long double>
3632  periodic_zetal(long double __x, long double __s)
3633  { return std::__detail::__periodic_zeta<long double>(__x, __s); }
3634 
3635  /**
3636  * Return the periodic zeta function of real argument @f$ x @f$,
3637  * and parameter @f$ s @f$.
3638  *
3639  * The the periodic zeta function is defined by
3640  * @f[
3641  * F(x, s) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{e^{i2\pi nx}}{n^s}
3642  * @f]
3643  *
3644  * @param __x The argument.
3645  * @param __s The order.
3646  */
3647  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up>
3648  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<std::complex<_Tp>, _Up>
3649  periodic_zeta(_Tp __x, _Up __s)
3650  {
3651  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up>;
3652  return std::__detail::__periodic_zeta<__type>(__x, __s);
3653  }
3654 
3655  /**
3656  * Return the periodic zeta function of complex argument @f$ z @f$,
3657  * and real parameter @f$ s @f$.
3658  *
3659  * @see periodic_zeta for details.
3660  */
3661  template<typename _Tp, typename _Up>
3662  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<std::complex<_Tp>, std::complex<_Up>>
3663  periodic_zeta(std::complex<_Up> __z, _Tp __s)
3664  {
3665  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Up>;
3666  return std::__detail::__periodic_zeta<__type>(__z, __s);
3667  }
3668 
3669  // Digamma or psi functions
3670 
3671  /**
3672  * Return the digamma or psi function of @c float argument @f$ x @f$.
3673  *
3674  * @see digamma for details.
3675  */
3676  inline float
3677  digammaf(float __x)
3678  { return std::__detail::__digamma<float>(__x); }
3679 
3680  /**
3681  * Return the digamma or psi function of <tt>long double</tt> argument
3682  * @f$ x @f$.
3683  *
3684  * @see digamma for details.
3685  */
3686  inline long double
3687  digammal(long double __x)
3688  { return std::__detail::__digamma<long double>(__x); }
3689 
3690  /**
3691  * Return the digamma or psi function of argument @f$ x @f$.
3692  *
3693  * The the digamma or psi function is defined by
3694  * @f[
3695  * \psi(x) = \frac{d}{dx}log\left(\Gamma(x)\right)
3696  * = \frac{\Gamma'(x)}{\Gamma(x)},
3697  * @f]
3698  * the logarithmic derivative of the gamma function.
3699  *
3700  * @param __x The parameter
3701  */
3702  template<typename _Tp>
3703  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3704  digamma(_Tp __x)
3705  {
3706  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3707  return std::__detail::__digamma<__type>(__x);
3708  }
3709 
3710  // Polygamma or psi functions
3711 
3712  /**
3713  * Return the polygamma function of @c float argument @f$ x @f$.
3714  *
3715  * @see polygamma for details.
3716  */
3717  inline float
3718  polygammaf(unsigned int __m, float __x)
3719  { return std::__detail::__polygamma<float>(__m, __x); }
3720 
3721  /**
3722  * Return the polygamma function of <tt>long double</tt> argument
3723  * @f$ x @f$.
3724  *
3725  * @see polygamma for details.
3726  */
3727  inline long double
3728  polygammal(unsigned int __m, long double __x)
3729  { return std::__detail::__polygamma<long double>(__m, __x); }
3730 
3731  /**
3732  * Return the polygamma function of argument @f$ x @f$.
3733  *
3734  * The the polygamma or digamma function is defined by
3735  * @f[
3736  * \psi(x) = \frac{d}{dx}log\left(\Gamma(x)\right)
3737  * = \frac{\Gamma'(x)}{\Gamma(x)}
3738  * @f]
3739  *
3740  * @param __m The order
3741  * @param __x The parameter
3742  */
3743  template<typename _Tp>
3744  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3745  polygamma(unsigned int __m, _Tp __x)
3746  {
3747  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3748  return std::__detail::__polygamma<__type>(__m, __x);
3749  }
3750 
3751  /**
3752  * Return the harmonic number @f$ H_n @f$.
3753  *
3754  * The the harmonic number is defined by
3755  * @f[
3756  * H_n = \sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{k}
3757  * @f]
3758  *
3759  * @param __n The parameter
3760  */
3761  template<typename _Tp>
3762  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3763  harmonic(unsigned int __n)
3764  {
3765  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3766  return std::__detail::__harmonic_number<__type>(__n);
3767  }
3768 
3769  // Incomplete beta functions
3770 
3771  /**
3772  * Return the regularized incomplete beta function of parameters
3773  * @f$ a @f$, @f$ b @f$, and argument @f$ x @f$.
3774  *
3775  * See ibeta for details.
3776  */
3777  inline float
3778  ibetaf(float __a, float __b, float __x)
3779  { return std::__detail::__beta_inc<float>(__a, __b, __x); }
3780 
3781  /**
3782  * Return the regularized incomplete beta function of parameters @f$ a @f$, @f$ b @f$,
3783  * and argument @f$ x @f$.
3784  *
3785  * See ibeta for details.
3786  */
3787  inline long double
3788  ibetal(long double __a, long double __b, long double __x)
3789  { return std::__detail::__beta_inc<long double>(__a, __b, __x); }
3790 
3791  /**
3792  * Return the regularized incomplete beta function of parameters @f$ a @f$, @f$ b @f$,
3793  * and argument @f$ x @f$.
3794  *
3795  * The regularized incomplete beta function is defined by
3796  * @f[
3797  * I_x(a, b) = \frac{B_x(a,b)}{B(a,b)}
3798  * @f]
3799  * where
3800  * @f[
3801  * B_x(a,b) = \int_0^x t^{a - 1} (1 - t)^{b - 1} dt
3802  * @f]
3803  * is the non-regularized incomplete beta function and @f$ B(a,b) @f$
3804  * is the usual beta function.
3805  *
3806  * @param __a The first parameter
3807  * @param __b The second parameter
3808  * @param __x The argument
3809  */
3810  template<typename _Ta, typename _Tb, typename _Tp>
3811  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tb, _Tp>
3812  ibeta(_Ta __a, _Tb __b, _Tp __x)
3813  {
3814  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tb, _Tp>;
3815  return std::__detail::__beta_inc<__type>(__a, __b, __x);
3816  }
3817 
3818  // Complementary incomplete beta functions
3819 
3820  inline float
3821  ibetacf(float __a, float __b, float __x)
3822  { return 1.0F - ibetaf(__a, __b, __x); }
3823 
3824  inline long double
3825  ibetacl(long double __a, long double __b, long double __x)
3826  { return 1.0L - ibetal(__a, __b, __x); }
3827 
3828  /**
3829  * Return the regularized complementary incomplete beta function
3830  * of parameters @f$ a @f$, @f$ b @f$, and argument @f$ x @f$.
3831  *
3832  * The regularized complementary incomplete beta function is defined by
3833  * @f[
3834  * I_x(a, b) = I_x(a, b)
3835  * @f]
3836  *
3837  * @param __a The parameter
3838  * @param __b The parameter
3839  * @param __x The argument
3840  */
3841  template<typename _Ta, typename _Tb, typename _Tp>
3842  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tb, _Tp>
3843  ibetac(_Ta __a, _Tb __b, _Tp __x)
3844  {
3845  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tb, _Tp>;
3846  return __type(1) - ibeta<__type>(__a, __b, __x);
3847  }
3848 
3849  // Fresnel sine integral
3850 
3851  inline float
3852  fresnel_sf(float __x)
3853  { return std::imag(std::__detail::__fresnel<float>(__x)); }
3854 
3855  inline long double
3856  fresnel_sl(long double __x)
3857  { return std::imag(std::__detail::__fresnel<long double>(__x)); }
3858 
3859  /**
3860  * Return the Fresnel sine integral of argument @f$ x @f$.
3861  *
3862  * The Fresnel sine integral is defined by
3863  * @f[
3864  * S(x) = \int_0^x \sin(\frac{\pi}{2}t^2) dt
3865  * @f]
3866  *
3867  * @param __x The argument
3868  */
3869  template<typename _Tp>
3870  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3871  fresnel_s(_Tp __x)
3872  {
3873  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3874  return std::imag(std::__detail::__fresnel<__type>(__x));
3875  }
3876 
3877  // Fresnel cosine integral
3878 
3879  inline float
3880  fresnel_cf(float __x)
3881  { return std::real(std::__detail::__fresnel<float>(__x)); }
3882 
3883  inline long double
3884  fresnel_cl(long double __x)
3885  { return std::real(std::__detail::__fresnel<long double>(__x)); }
3886 
3887  /**
3888  * Return the Fresnel cosine integral of argument @f$ x @f$.
3889  *
3890  * The Fresnel cosine integral is defined by
3891  * @f[
3892  * C(x) = \int_0^x \cos(\frac{\pi}{2}t^2) dt
3893  * @f]
3894  *
3895  * @param __x The argument
3896  */
3897  template<typename _Tp>
3898  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3899  fresnel_c(_Tp __x)
3900  {
3901  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3902  return std::real(std::__detail::__fresnel<__type>(__x));
3903  }
3904 
3905  // Dawson integral
3906 
3907  /**
3908  * Return the Dawson integral, @f$ F(x) @f$, for @c float argument @f$ x @f$.
3909  *
3910  * @see dawson for details.
3911  */
3912  inline float
3913  dawsonf(float __x)
3914  { return std::__detail::__dawson<float>(__x); }
3915 
3916  /**
3917  * Return the Dawson integral, @f$ F(x) @f$,
3918  * for <tt>long double</tt> argument @f$ x @f$.
3919  *
3920  * @see dawson for details.
3921  */
3922  inline long double
3923  dawsonl(long double __x)
3924  { return std::__detail::__dawson<long double>(__x); }
3925 
3926  /**
3927  * Return the Dawson integral, @f$ F(x) @f$, for real argument @f$ x @f$.
3928  *
3929  * The Dawson integral is defined by:
3930  * @f[
3931  * F(x) = e^{-x^2}\int_0^x e^{y^2}dy
3932  * @f]
3933  * and it's derivative is:
3934  * @f[
3935  * F'(x) = 1 - 2xF(x)
3936  * @f]
3937  *
3938  * @param __x The argument @f$ -inf < x < inf @f$.
3939  */
3940  template<typename _Tp>
3941  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3942  dawson(_Tp __x)
3943  {
3944  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3945  return std::__detail::__dawson<__type>(__x);
3946  }
3947 
3948  // Exponential integrals
3949 
3950  /**
3951  * Return the exponential integral @f$ E_n(x) @f$ for integral
3952  * order @f$ n @f$ and @c float argument @f$ x @f$.
3953  *
3954  * @see expint for details.
3955  */
3956  inline float
3957  expintf(unsigned int __n, float __x)
3958  { return std::__detail::__expint<float>(__n, __x); }
3959 
3960  /**
3961  * Return the exponential integral @f$ E_n(x) @f$ for integral
3962  * order @f$ n @f$ and <tt>long double</tt> argument @f$ x @f$.
3963  *
3964  * @see expint for details.
3965  */
3966  inline long double
3967  expintl(unsigned int __n, long double __x)
3968  { return std::__detail::__expint<long double>(__n, __x); }
3969 
3970  /**
3971  * Return the exponential integral @f$ E_n(x) @f$ of integral
3972  * order @f$ n @f$ and real argument @f$ x @f$.
3973  * The exponential integral is defined by:
3974  * @f[
3975  * E_n(x) = \int_1^\infty \frac{e^{-tx}}{t^n}dt
3976  * @f]
3977  * In particular
3978  * @f[
3979  * E_1(x) = \int_1^\infty \frac{e^{-tx}}{t}dt = -Ei(-x)
3980  * @f]
3981  *
3982  * @tparam _Tp The real type of the argument
3983  * @param __n The integral order
3984  * @param __x The real argument
3985  */
3986  template<typename _Tp>
3987  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
3988  expint(unsigned int __n, _Tp __x)
3989  {
3990  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
3991  return std::__detail::__expint<__type>(__n, __x);
3992  }
3993 
3994  // Log rising factorials
3995 
3996  /**
3997  * Return the logarithm of the rising factorial @f$ a^{\overline{\nu}} @f$
3998  * for float arguments.
3999  *
4000  * @see lrising_factorial for details.
4001  */
4002  inline float
4003  lrising_factorialf(float __a, float __nu)
4004  { return std::__detail::__log_rising_factorial<float>(__a, __nu); }
4005 
4006  /**
4007  * Return the logarithm of the rising factorial @f$ ln(a^{\overline{\nu}}) @f$
4008  * for <tt> long double </tt> arguments.
4009  *
4010  * @see lrising_factorial for details.
4011  */
4012  inline long double
4013  lrising_factoriall(long double __a, long double __nu)
4014  { return std::__detail::__log_rising_factorial<long double>(__a, __nu); }
4015 
4016  /**
4017  * @brief Return the logarithm of the rising factorial function
4018  * or the (upper) Pochhammer symbol.
4019  * The rising factorial function is defined for integer order by
4020  * @f[
4021  * a^{\overline{\nu}} = \Gamma(a + \nu) / \Gamma(n)
4022  * = \prod_{k=0}^{\nu-1} (a + k), \overline{0} \equiv 1
4023  * @f]
4024  * Thus this function returns
4025  * @f[
4026  * ln[a^{\overline{\nu}}] = ln[\Gamma(a + \nu)] - ln[\Gamma(\nu)],
4027  * ln[a^{\overline{0}}] \equiv 0
4028  * @f]
4029  * Many notations exist for this function: @f$ (a)_\nu @f$, called
4030  * the Pochhammer function (esp. in the literature of special functions), and
4031  * @f[ \left[ \begin{array}{c}
4032  * a \\
4033  * \nu \end{array} \right]
4034  * @f], and others.
4035  */
4036  template<typename _Tp, typename _Tnu>
4037  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>
4038  lrising_factorial(_Tp __a, _Tnu __nu)
4039  {
4040  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>;
4041  return std::__detail::__log_rising_factorial<__type>(__a, __nu);
4042  }
4043 
4044  // Log falling factorials
4045 
4046  /**
4047  * Return the logarithm of the falling factorial @f$ ln(a^{\overline{\nu}})@f$
4048  * for float arguments.
4049  *
4050  * @see lfalling_factorial for details.
4051  */
4052  inline float
4053  lfalling_factorialf(float __a, float __nu)
4054  { return std::__detail::__log_falling_factorial<float>(__a, __nu); }
4055 
4056  /**
4057  * Return the logarithm of the falling factorial @f$ ln(a^{\overline{\nu}})@f$
4058  * for float arguments.
4059  *
4060  * @see lfalling_factorial for details.
4061  */
4062  inline long double
4063  lfalling_factoriall(long double __a, long double __nu)
4064  { return std::__detail::__log_falling_factorial<long double>(__a, __nu); }
4065 
4066  /**
4067  * @brief Return the logarithm of the falling factorial function
4068  * or the lower Pochhammer symbol.
4069  * The falling factorial function is defined by
4070  * @f[
4071  * a^{\underline{n}} = \frac{\Gamma(a + 1)}{\Gamma(a - \nu + 1)}
4072  * = \prod_{k=0}^{n-1} (a - k)
4073  * @f]
4074  * where @f$ a^{\underline{0}} \equiv 1 @f$.
4075  * In particular, @f$ n^{\underline{n}} = n! @f$.
4076  * Thus this function returns
4077  * @f[
4078  * ln[a^{\underline{n}}] = ln[\Gamma(a + 1)] - ln[\Gamma(a - \nu + 1)]
4079  * @f]
4080  * where @f$ ln[a^{\underline{0}}] \equiv 0 @f$.
4081  * Many notations exist for this function: @f$ (a)_\nu @f$,
4082  * @f[
4083  * \{ \begin{array}{c}
4084  * a \\
4085  * \nu \end{array} \}
4086  * @f], and others.
4087  */
4088  template<typename _Tp, typename _Tnu>
4089  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>
4090  lfalling_factorial(_Tp __a, _Tnu __nu)
4091  {
4092  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>;
4093  return std::__detail::__log_falling_factorial<__type>(__a, __nu);
4094  }
4095 
4096  // Rising factorials
4097 
4098  /**
4099  * Return the rising factorial @f$ a^{\overline{\nu}} @f$
4100  * for float arguments.
4101  *
4102  * @see rising_factorial for details.
4103  */
4104  inline float
4105  rising_factorialf(float __a, float __nu)
4106  { return std::__detail::__rising_factorial<float>(__a, __nu); }
4107 
4108  /**
4109  * Return the rising factorial @f$ a^{\overline{\nu}} @f$
4110  * for <tt> long double </tt> arguments.
4111  *
4112  * @see rising_factorial for details.
4113  */
4114  inline long double
4115  rising_factoriall(long double __a, long double __nu)
4116  { return std::__detail::__rising_factorial<long double>(__a, __nu); }
4117 
4118  /**
4119  * @brief Return the rising factorial function
4120  * or the (upper) Pochhammer function.
4121  * The rising factorial function is defined by
4122  * @f[
4123  * a^{\overline{\nu}} = \Gamma(a + \nu) / \Gamma(\nu)
4124  * @f]
4125  * Many notations exist for this function: @f$ (a)_\nu @f$, called
4126  * the Pochhammer function (esp. in the literature of special functions), and
4127  * @f[ \left[ \begin{array}{c}
4128  * a \\
4129  * \nu \end{array} \right]
4130  * @f], and others.
4131  */
4132  template<typename _Tp, typename _Tnu>
4133  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>
4134  rising_factorial(_Tp __a, _Tnu __nu)
4135  {
4136  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>;
4137  return std::__detail::__rising_factorial<__type>(__a, __nu);
4138  }
4139 
4140  // Falling factorials
4141 
4142  /**
4143  * Return the falling factorial @f$ a^{\underline{\nu}} @f$
4144  * for float arguments.
4145  *
4146  * @see falling_factorial for details.
4147  */
4148  inline float
4149  falling_factorialf(float __a, float __nu)
4150  { return std::__detail::__falling_factorial<float>(__a, __nu); }
4151 
4152  /**
4153  * Return the falling factorial @f$ a^{\underline{\nu}} @f$
4154  * for <tt> long double </tt> arguments.
4155  *
4156  * @see falling_factorial for details.
4157  */
4158  inline long double
4159  falling_factoriall(long double __a, long double __nu)
4160  { return std::__detail::__falling_factorial<long double>(__a, __nu); }
4161 
4162  /**
4163  * @brief Return the falling factorial function
4164  * or the lower Pochhammer symbol for real argument @f$ a @f$
4165  * and integral order @f$ n @f$.
4166  * The falling factorial function is defined by
4167  * @f[
4168  * a^{\underline{n}} = \prod_{k=0}^{n-1} (a - k)
4169  * = \Gamma(a + 1) / \Gamma(a - n + 1)
4170  * @f]
4171  * where @f$ a^{\underline{0}} \equiv 1 @f$.
4172  * In particular, @f$ n^{\underline{n}} = n! @f$.
4173  */
4174  template<typename _Tp, typename _Tnu>
4175  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>
4176  falling_factorial(_Tp __a, _Tnu __nu)
4177  {
4178  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp, _Tnu>;
4179  return std::__detail::__falling_factorial<__type>(__a, __nu);
4180  }
4181 
4182  // Factorial
4183 
4184  /**
4185  * Return the factorial @f$ n! @f$ of the argument as a @c float.
4186  *
4187  * @see factorial for more details
4188  */
4189  inline float
4190  factorialf(unsigned int __n)
4191  { return std::__detail::__factorial<float>(__n); }
4192 
4193  /**
4194  * Return the factorial @f$ n! @f$ of the argument as a <tt>long double</tt>.
4195  *
4196  * @see factorial for more details
4197  */
4198  inline long double
4199  factoriall(unsigned int __n)
4200  { return std::__detail::__factorial<long double>(__n); }
4201 
4202  /**
4203  * @brief Return the factorial @f$ n! @f$ of the argument as a real number.
4204  * @f[
4205  * n! = 1 \times 2 \times ... \times n, 0! = 1
4206  * @f]
4207  */
4208  template<typename _Tp>
4209  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4210  factorial(unsigned int __n)
4211  {
4212  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4213  return std::__detail::__factorial<__type>(__n);
4214  }
4215 
4216  // Double factorial
4217 
4218  /**
4219  * Return the double factorial @f$ n!! @f$ of the argument as a @c float.
4220  *
4221  * @see double_factorial for more details
4222  */
4223  inline float
4224  double_factorialf(int __n)
4225  { return std::__detail::__double_factorial<float>(__n); }
4226 
4227  /**
4228  * Return the double factorial @f$ n!! @f$ of the argument
4229  * as a <tt> long double </tt>.
4230  *
4231  * @see double_factorial for more details
4232  */
4233  inline long double
4234  double_factoriall(int __n)
4235  { return std::__detail::__double_factorial<long double>(__n); }
4236 
4237  /**
4238  * @brief Return the double factorial @f$ n!! @f$ of the argument
4239  * as a real number.
4240  * @f[
4241  * n!! = n(n-2)...(2), 0!! = 1
4242  * @f]
4243  * for even @f$ n @f$ and
4244  * @f[
4245  * n!! = n(n-2)...(1), (-1)!! = 1
4246  * @f]
4247  * for odd @f$ n @f$.
4248  */
4249  template<typename _Tp>
4250  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4251  double_factorial(int __n)
4252  {
4253  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4254  return std::__detail::__double_factorial<__type>(__n);
4255  }
4256 
4257  // Log factorial
4258 
4259  /**
4260  * Return the logarithm of the factorial @f$ ln(n!) @f$ of the argument
4261  * as a @c float.
4262  *
4263  * @see lfactorial for more details
4264  */
4265  inline float
4266  lfactorialf(unsigned int __n)
4267  { return std::__detail::__log_factorial<float>(__n); }
4268 
4269  /**
4270  * Return the logarithm of the factorial @f$ ln(n!) @f$ of the argument
4271  * as a <tt>long double</tt>.
4272  *
4273  * @see lfactorial for more details
4274  */
4275  inline long double
4276  lfactoriall(unsigned int __n)
4277  { return std::__detail::__log_factorial<long double>(__n); }
4278 
4279  /**
4280  * @brief Return the logarithm of the factorial @f$ ln(n!) @f$ of the argument
4281  * as a real number.
4282  * @f[
4283  * n! = 1 \times 2 \times ... \times n, 0! = 1
4284  * @f]
4285  */
4286  template<typename _Tp>
4287  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4288  lfactorial(unsigned int __n)
4289  {
4290  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4291  return std::__detail::__log_factorial<__type>(__n);
4292  }
4293 
4294  // Log double factorial
4295 
4296  /**
4297  * Return the logarithm of the double factorial @f$ ln(n!!) @f$
4298  * of the argument as a @c float.
4299  *
4300  * @see ldouble_factorial for more details
4301  */
4302  inline float
4303  ldouble_factorialf(int __n)
4304  { return std::__detail::__log_double_factorial<float>(__n); }
4305 
4306  /**
4307  * Return the logarithm of the double factorial @f$ ln(n!!) @f$
4308  * of the argument as a <tt> long double </tt>.
4309  *
4310  * @see double_factorial for more details
4311  */
4312  inline long double
4313  ldouble_factoriall(int __n)
4314  { return std::__detail::__log_double_factorial<long double>(__n); }
4315 
4316  /**
4317  * @brief Return the logarithm of the double factorial @f$ ln(n!!) @f$
4318  * of the argument as a real number.
4319  * @f[
4320  * n!! = n(n-2)...(2), 0!! = 1
4321  * @f]
4322  * for even @f$ n @f$ and
4323  * @f[
4324  * n!! = n(n-2)...(1), (-1)!! = 1
4325  * @f]
4326  * for odd @f$ n @f$.
4327  */
4328  template<typename _Tp>
4329  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4330  ldouble_factorial(int __n)
4331  {
4332  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4333  return std::__detail::__log_double_factorial<__type>(__n);
4334  }
4335 
4336  // Binomial coefficient
4337 
4338  /**
4339  * Return the binomial coefficient as a @c float.
4340  *
4341  * @see binomial for details.
4342  */
4343  inline float
4344  binomialf(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __k)
4345  { return std::__detail::__binomial<float>(__n, __k); }
4346 
4347  /**
4348  * Return the binomial coefficient as a <tt>long double</tt>.
4349  *
4350  * @see binomial for details.
4351  */
4352  inline long double
4353  binomiall(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __k)
4354  { return std::__detail::__binomial<long double>(__n, __k); }
4355 
4356  /**
4357  * @brief Return the binomial coefficient as a real number.
4358  * The binomial coefficient is given by:
4359  * @f[
4360  * \binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{(n-k)! k!}
4361  * @f]
4362  * The binomial coefficients are generated by:
4363  * @f[
4364  * \left(1 + t\right)^n = \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} t^k
4365  * @f]
4366  *
4367  * @param __n The first argument of the binomial coefficient.
4368  * @param __k The second argument of the binomial coefficient.
4369  * @return The binomial coefficient.
4370  */
4371  template<typename _Tp>
4372  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4373  binomial(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __k)
4374  {
4375  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4376  return std::__detail::__binomial<__type>(__n, __k);
4377  }
4378 
4379  // Log binomial coefficient
4380 
4381  /**
4382  * Return the logarithm of the binomial coefficient as a @c float.
4383  *
4384  * @see lbinomial for details.
4385  */
4386  inline float
4387  lbinomialf(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __k)
4388  { return std::__detail::__log_binomial<float>(__n, __k); }
4389 
4390  /**
4391  * Return the logarithm of the binomial coefficient as a <tt>long double</tt>.
4392  *
4393  * @see lbinomial for details.
4394  */
4395  inline long double
4396  lbinomiall(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __k)
4397  { return std::__detail::__log_binomial<long double>(__n, __k); }
4398 
4399  /**
4400  * @brief Return the logarithm of the binomial coefficient as a real number.
4401  * The binomial coefficient is given by:
4402  * @f[
4403  * \binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{(n-k)! k!}
4404  * @f]
4405  * The binomial coefficients are generated by:
4406  * @f[
4407  * \left(1 + t\right)^n = \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} t^k
4408  * @f]
4409  *
4410  * @param __n The first argument of the binomial coefficient.
4411  * @param __k The second argument of the binomial coefficient.
4412  * @return The logarithm of the binomial coefficient.
4413  */
4414  template<typename _Tp>
4415  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4416  lbinomial(unsigned int __n, unsigned int __k)
4417  {
4418  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4419  return std::__detail::__log_binomial<__type>(__n, __k);
4420  }
4421 
4422  // Bernoulli numbers
4423 
4424  /**
4425  * Return the Bernoulli number of integer order @f$ n @f$ as a @c float.
4426  *
4427  * @see bernoulli for details.
4428  */
4429  inline float
4430  bernoullif(unsigned int __n)
4431  { return std::__detail::__bernoulli<float>(__n); }
4432 
4433  /**
4434  * Return the Bernoulli number of integer order @f$ n @f$ as a
4435  * <tt>long double</tt>.
4436  *
4437  * @see bernoulli for details.
4438  */
4439  inline long double
4440  bernoullil(unsigned int __n)
4441  { return std::__detail::__bernoulli<long double>(__n); }
4442 
4443  /**
4444  * Return the Bernoulli number of integer order @f$ n @f$.
4445  *
4446  * The Bernoulli numbers are defined by
4447  * @f[
4448  * B_{2n} = (-1)^{n+1} 2\frac{(2n)!}{(2\pi)^{2n}} \zeta(2n),
4449  * B_1 = -1/2
4450  * @f]
4451  * All odd Bernoulli numbers except @f$ B_1 @f$ are zero.
4452  *
4453  * @param __n The order.
4454  */
4455  template<typename _Tp>
4456  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4457  bernoulli(unsigned int __n)
4458  {
4459  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4460  return std::__detail::__bernoulli<__type>(__n);
4461  }
4462 
4463  // Legendre functions of the second kind
4464 
4465  /**
4466  * Return the Legendre function of the second kind @f$ Q_l(x) @f$
4467  * of nonnegative degree @f$ l @f$ and @c float argument.
4468  *
4469  * @see legendre_q for details.
4470  */
4471  inline float
4472  legendre_qf(unsigned int __l, float __x)
4473  { return std::__detail::__legendre_q<float>(__l, __x).__Q_l; }
4474 
4475  /**
4476  * Return the Legendre function of the second kind @f$ Q_l(x) @f$
4477  * of nonnegative degree @f$ l @f$ and <tt>long double</tt> argument.
4478  *
4479  * @see legendre_q for details.
4480  */
4481  inline long double
4482  legendre_ql(unsigned int __l, long double __x)
4483  { return std::__detail::__legendre_q<long double>(__l, __x).__Q_l; }
4484 
4485  /**
4486  * Return the Legendre function of the second kind @f$ Q_l(x) @f$ of
4487  * nonnegative degree @f$ l @f$ and real argument @f$ |x| <= 0 @f$.
4488  *
4489  * The Legendre function of the second kind of order @f$ l @f$
4490  * and argument @f$ x @f$, @f$ Q_l(x) @f$, is defined by:
4491  * @f[
4492  * Q_l(x) = \frac{1}{2} \log{\frac{x+1}{x-1}} P_l(x)
4493  * - \sum_{k=0}^{l-1}\frac{(l+k)!}{(l-k)!(k!)^2 s^k}
4494  * \left[\psi(l+1) - \psi(k+1)\right](x-1)^k
4495  * @f]
4496  * where @f$ P_l(x) @f$ is the Legendre polynomial of degree @f$ l @f$
4497  * and @f$ \psi(x) @f$ is the digamma or psi function which for integral
4498  * argument is related to the harmonic number:
4499  * @f$ \psi(n) = -\gamma_E + H_n @f$.
4500  *
4501  * @tparam _Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c __x.
4502  * @param __l The degree @f$ l >= 0 @f$
4503  * @param __x The argument @c abs(__x) <= 1
4504  * @throw std::domain_error if @c abs(__x) > 1
4505  */
4506  template<typename _Tp>
4507  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4508  legendre_q(unsigned int __l, _Tp __x)
4509  {
4510  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4511  return std::__detail::__legendre_q<__type>(__l, __x).__Q_l;
4512  }
4513 
4514  // Associated Legendre functions of the second kind
4515 
4516  /**
4517  * Return the associated Legendre function @f$ Q_l^m(x) @f$
4518  * of degree @f$ l @f$, order @f$ m @f$, and @c float argument @f$ x @f$.
4519  *
4520  * @see assoc_legendre_q for more details.
4521  */
4522  inline float
4523  assoc_legendre_qf(unsigned int __l, unsigned int __m, float __x)
4524  { return std::__detail::__assoc_legendre_q<float>(__l, __m, __x).__Q_lm; }
4525 
4526  /**
4527  * Return the associated Legendre function @f$ Q_l^m(x) @f$
4528  * of degree @f$ l @f$, order @f$ m @f$, and @c <tt>long double</tt>
4529  * argument @f$ x @f$.
4530  *
4531  * @see assoc_legendre_q for more details.
4532  */
4533  inline long double
4534  assoc_legendre_ql(unsigned int __l, unsigned int __m, long double __x)
4535  {
4536  return std::__detail::__assoc_legendre_q<long double>(__l, __m, __x).__Q_lm;
4537  }
4538 
4539  /**
4540  * Return the associated Legendre function @f$ Q_l^m(x) @f$
4541  * of degree @f$ l @f$, order @f$ m @f$, and real argument @f$ x @f$.
4542  *
4543  * The associated Legendre function is derived from the Legendre function
4544  * @f$ Q_l(x) @f$ by the Rodrigues formula:
4545  * @f[
4546  * Q_l^m(x) = (1 - x^2)^{m/2}\frac{d^m}{dx^m}Q_l(x)
4547  * @f]
4548  * @see legendre for details of the Legendre function of degree @c l
4549  * @note @f$ Q_l^m(x) != 0 @f$ if @f$ m > l @f$.
4550  *
4551  * @tparam _Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c __x.
4552  * @param __l The degree <tt>__l >= 0</tt>.
4553  * @param __m The order <tt>__m</tt>.
4554  * @param __x The argument, <tt>abs(__x) <= 1</tt>.
4555  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt>abs(__x) > 1</tt>.
4556  */
4557  template<typename _Tp>
4558  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>
4559  assoc_legendre_q(unsigned int __l, unsigned int __m, _Tp __x)
4560  {
4561  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tp>;
4562  return std::__detail::__assoc_legendre_q<__type>(__l, __m, __x).__Q_lm;
4563  }
4564 
4565  // Scaled lower incomplete gamma
4566 
4567  inline float
4568  gamma_pf(float __a, float __x)
4569  { return std::__detail::__gamma_p<float>(__a, __x); }
4570 
4571  inline long double
4572  gamma_pl(long double __a, long double __x)
4573  { return std::__detail::__gamma_p<long double>(__a, __x); }
4574 
4575  /**
4576  * @brief Return the gamma cumulative propability distribution function
4577  * or the regularized lower incomplete gamma function.
4578  *
4579  * The formula for the gamma probability density function is:
4580  * @f[
4581  * \Gamma(x|\alpha,\beta) = \frac{1}{\beta\Gamma(\alpha)}
4582  * (x/\beta)^{\alpha - 1} e^{-x/\beta}
4583  * @f]
4584  */
4585  template<typename _Ta, typename _Tp>
4586  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>
4587  gamma_p(_Ta __a, _Tp __x)
4588  {
4589  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>;
4590  return std::__detail::__gamma_p<__type>(__a, __x);
4591  }
4592 
4593  // Scaled upper incomplete gamma
4594 
4595  inline float
4596  gamma_qf(float __a, float __x)
4597  { return std::__detail::__gamma_q<float>(__a, __x); }
4598 
4599  inline long double
4600  gamma_ql(long double __a, long double __x)
4601  { return std::__detail::__gamma_q<long double>(__a, __x); }
4602 
4603  /**
4604  * @brief Return the gamma complementary cumulative propability distribution
4605  * (or survival) function or the regularized upper incomplete gamma function.
4606  *
4607  * The formula for the gamma probability density function is:
4608  * @f[
4609  * \Gamma(x|\alpha,\beta) = \frac{1}{\beta\Gamma(\alpha)}
4610  * (x/\beta)^{\alpha - 1} e^{-x/\beta}
4611  * @f]
4612  */
4613  template<typename _Ta, typename _Tp>
4614  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>
4615  gamma_q(_Ta __a,_Tp __x)
4616  {
4617  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Ta, _Tp>;
4618  return std::__detail::__gamma_q<__type>(__a, __x);
4619  }
4620 
4621  // Jacobi zeta functions.
4622 
4623  inline float
4624  jacobi_zetaf(float __k, float __phi)
4625  { return std::__detail::__jacobi_zeta<float>(__k, __phi); }
4626 
4627  inline long double
4628  jacobi_zetal(long double __k, long double __phi)
4629  { return std::__detail::__jacobi_zeta<long double>(__k, __phi); }
4630 
4631  /**
4632  * Return the Jacobi zeta function of @f$ k @f$ and @f$ \phi @f$.
4633  *
4634  * The Jacobi zeta function is defined by
4635  * @f[
4636  * Z(m,\phi) = E(m,\phi) - \frac{E(m)F(m,\phi)}{K(m)}
4637  * @f]
4638  * where @f$ E(m,\phi) @f$ is the elliptic function of the second kind,
4639  * @f$ E(m) @f$ is the complete ellitic function of the second kind,
4640  * and @f$ F(m,\phi) @f$ is the elliptic function of the first kind.
4641  *
4642  * @tparam _Tk the real type of the modulus
4643  * @tparam _Tphi the real type of the angle limit
4644  * @param __k The modulus
4645  * @param __phi The angle
4646  */
4647  template<typename _Tk, typename _Tphi>
4648  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>
4649  jacobi_zeta(_Tk __k, _Tphi __phi)
4650  {
4651  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>;
4652  return std::__detail::__jacobi_zeta<__type>(__k, __phi);
4653  }
4654 
4655  // Heuman lambda functions.
4656 
4657  inline float
4658  heuman_lambdaf(float __k, float __phi)
4659  { return std::__detail::__heuman_lambda<float>(__k, __phi); }
4660 
4661  inline long double
4662  heuman_lambdal(long double __k, long double __phi)
4663  { return std::__detail::__heuman_lambda<long double>(__k, __phi); }
4664 
4665  /**
4666  * Return the Heuman lambda function @f$ \Lambda(k,\phi) @f$
4667  * of modulus @f$ k @f$ and angular limit @f$ \phi @f$.
4668  *
4669  * The complete Heuman lambda function is defined by
4670  * @f[
4671  * \Lambda(k,\phi) = \frac{F(1-m,\phi)}{K(1-m)}
4672  * + \frac{2}{\pi} K(m) Z(1-m,\phi)
4673  * @f]
4674  * where @f$ m = k^2 @f$, @f$ K(k) @f$ is the complete elliptic function
4675  * of the first kind, and @f$ Z(k,\phi) @f$ is the Jacobi zeta function.
4676  *
4677  * @tparam _Tk the floating-point type of the modulus
4678  * @tparam _Tphi the floating-point type of the angular limit argument
4679  * @param __k The modulus
4680  * @param __phi The angle
4681  */
4682  template<typename _Tk, typename _Tphi>
4683  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>
4684  heuman_lambda(_Tk __k, _Tphi __phi)
4685  {
4686  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>;
4687  return std::__detail::__heuman_lambda<__type>(__k, __phi);
4688  }
4689 
4690  // Complete Legendre elliptic integral D.
4691 
4692  /**
4693  * Return the complete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k) @f$
4694  * of @c float modulus @f$ k @f$.
4695  *
4696  * @see comp_ellint_d for details.
4697  */
4698  inline float
4699  comp_ellint_df(float __k)
4700  { return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_d<float>(__k); }
4701 
4702  /**
4703  * Return the complete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k) @f$
4704  * of <tt>long double</tt> modulus @f$ k @f$.
4705  *
4706  * @see comp_ellint_d for details.
4707  */
4708  inline long double
4709  comp_ellint_dl(long double __k)
4710  { return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_d<long double>(__k); }
4711 
4712  /**
4713  * Return the complete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k) @f$
4714  * of real modulus @f$ k @f$.
4715  *
4716  * The complete Legendre elliptic integral D is defined by
4717  * @f[
4718  * D(k) = \int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\sin^2\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1-k^2sin2\theta}}
4719  * @f]
4720  *
4721  * @tparam _Tk The type of the modulus @c k
4722  * @param __k The modulus <tt>-1 <= __k <= +1</tt>
4723  */
4724  template<typename _Tk>
4725  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tk>
4726  comp_ellint_d(_Tk __k)
4727  {
4728  using __type = __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tk>;
4729  return std::__detail::__comp_ellint_d<__type>(__k);
4730  }
4731 
4732  // Legendre elliptic integrals D.
4733 
4734  /**
4735  * Return the incomplete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k, \phi) @f$
4736  * of @c float modulus @f$ k @f$ and angular limit @f$ \phi @f$.
4737  *
4738  * @see ellint_d for details.
4739  */
4740  inline float
4741  ellint_df(float __k, float __phi)
4742  { return std::__detail::__ellint_d<float>(__k, __phi); }
4743 
4744  /**
4745  * Return the incomplete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k, \phi) @f$
4746  * of <tt>long double</tt> modulus @f$ k @f$ and angular limit @f$ \phi @f$.
4747  *
4748  * @see ellint_d for details.
4749  */
4750  inline long double
4751  ellint_dl(long double __k, long double __phi)
4752  { return std::__detail::__ellint_d<long double>(__k, __phi); }
4753 
4754  /**
4755  * Return the incomplete Legendre elliptic integral @f$ D(k,\phi) @f$
4756  * of real modulus @f$ k @f$ and angular limit @f$ \phi @f$.
4757  *
4758  * The Legendre elliptic integral D is defined by
4759  * @f[
4760  * D(k,\phi) = \int_0^\phi
4761  * \frac{\sin^2\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1-k^2sin^2\theta}}
4762  * @f]
4763  *
4764  * @param __k The modulus <tt>-1 <= __k <= +1</tt>
4765  * @param __phi The angle
4766  */
4767  template<typename _Tk, typename _Tphi>
4768  inline __gnu_cxx::fp_promote_t<_Tk, _Tphi>
